<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 119, 378, 144]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 201]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NAME  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 221, 175, 250]]<|/det|>
CENTRE NUMBER

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 211, 905, 256]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 276, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
0625/41  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 299, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 Theory (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 300, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2022  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 325, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 383, 359, 399]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 574]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(10 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 603, 213, 618]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 619, 729, 651]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 803, 89]]<|/det|>
A car of mass \(m\) is travelling along a straight, horizontal road at a constant speed \(v\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
At time \(t = 0\), the driver of the car sees an obstruction in the road ahead of the car and applies the brakes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 494, 166]]<|/det|>
The car does **not** begin to decelerate at \(t = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 180, 146, 199]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 475, 198]]<|/det|>
Explain what is meant by deceleration.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 303, 144, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 303, 737, 322]]<|/det|>
Suggest one reason why the car does **not** begin to decelerate at \(t = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 395, 141, 414]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 395, 620, 414]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.1 is the distance–time graph for the car from \(t = 0\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 425, 809, 672]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 689, 532, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 720, 181, 739]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 720, 777, 739]]<|/det|>
State the property of a distance–time graph that corresponds to speed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 752, 920, 771]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 783, 181, 802]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 782, 640, 801]]<|/det|>
Using Fig. 1.1, determine the initial speed \(v\) of the car.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 875, 920, 893]]<|/det|>
<form>v = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 875, 920, 893]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 148, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
When the car is decelerating, there is a constant resistive force \(F\) on the car due to the brakes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 114, 695, 138]]<|/det|>
The deceleration of the car is greater than \(\frac{F}{m}\) and is not constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 265, 168]]<|/det|>
Explain why:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 181, 198]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 178, 559, 201]]<|/det|>
the deceleration of the car is greater than \(\frac{F}{m}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[851, 240, 920, 259]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 272, 181, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 272, 462, 291]]<|/det|>
the deceleration is not constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 395, 920, 414]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 395, 920, 414]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 693, 91]]<|/det|>
Fig. 2.1 shows water stored in a reservoir behind a hydroelectric dam.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[134, 98, 861, 401]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 416, 591, 435]]<|/det|>
<center>Fig. 2.1 (not to scale)</center>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 463, 146, 482]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 463, 920, 498]]<|/det|>
State the form of the energy stored in the water in the reservoir that is used to generate electricity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 510, 920, 528]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 540, 148, 559]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 540, 688, 559]]<|/det|>
The turbine is \(150 \text{m}\) below the level of the water in the reservoir.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 571, 764, 591]]<|/det|>
Atmospheric pressure is \(1.0 \times 10^{5} \text{Pa}\). The density of water is \(1000 \text{kg} / \text{m}^{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 603, 181, 621]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 603, 641, 621]]<|/det|>
Calculate the total pressure in the water at the turbine.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[490, 757, 920, 776]]<|/det|>
<form>pressure = .................................................... [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 180, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 594, 88]]<|/det|>
The turbine has a cross-sectional area of \(3.5 \text{m}^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 101, 648, 120]]<|/det|>
Calculate the force exerted on the turbine by the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[522, 226, 920, 244]]<|/det|>
<form>force = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 288, 146, 306]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 288, 798, 306]]<|/det|>
The water flows to the turbine through a pipe of constant cross-sectional area.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 319, 920, 354]]<|/det|>
Explain why the kinetic energy of the water in the pipe remains constant as it flows through the pipe.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 448, 920, 465]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 850, 91]]<|/det|>
During a picnic on a warm, dry day, a metal can of lemonade is wrapped in a damp cloth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 450, 121]]<|/det|>
Evaporation cools the water in the cloth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 133, 144, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 781, 152]]<|/det|>
Explain, in terms of molecules, how evaporation cools the water in the cloth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 287, 143, 306]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 287, 603, 306]]<|/det|>
As the water in the cloth cools, so does the lemonade.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 319, 777, 337]]<|/det|>
Explain how electrons transfer thermal energy through the metal of the can.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 444, 920, 464]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 473, 920, 492]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 598, 88]]<|/det|>
A thermocouple is a device that is used as a thermometer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 146, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
Fig. 4.1 shows a beaker that contains molten sulfur at an initial temperature greater than \(400^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 180, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 149, 920, 181]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 4.1, sketch and label a diagram of a thermocouple that is used to determine the temperature of the sulfur as it cools to room temperature.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[670, 329, 824, 389]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 421, 532, 440]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 437, 920, 455]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 469, 181, 488]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 467, 814, 486]]<|/det|>
Describe briefly how the temperature of the sulfur in the beaker is deduced.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 593, 146, 611]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 593, 920, 625]]<|/det|>
State one advantage of using a thermocouple to measure temperature rather than using a liquid-in-glass thermometer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 670, 920, 689]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 701, 920, 719]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 633, 89]]<|/det|>
Fig. 5.1 shows a kitchen tap that supplies instant boiling water.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[373, 100, 625, 304]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 318, 532, 336]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 349, 672, 367]]<|/det|>
Cold water passes over an electric immersion heater inside the tap.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 380, 411, 398]]<|/det|>
The boiling point of water is \(100^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 411, 146, 429]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 411, 455, 429]]<|/det|>
State what is meant by boiling point.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 503, 146, 521]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 503, 920, 536]]<|/det|>
The immersion heater is powered by the mains at a voltage of 230 V. When the tap is opened, the heater switches on and the current in the heater is 13A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 551, 180, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 551, 692, 570]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 658, 920, 676]]<|/det|>
<form>thermal energy = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 689, 181, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 689, 920, 721]]<|/det|>
The specific heat capacity of water is \(4200 \text{J} / (\text{kg} \degree \text{C})\). The cold water that enters the tap is at \(22 \degree \text{C}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 735, 801, 753]]<|/det|>
Calculate the rate at which water at its boiling point emerges from the tap.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[531, 907, 920, 924]]<|/det|>
<form>rate = ............................................................ [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
The metal tap is earthed and there is a fuse in the cable that connects the heater to the mains.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 180, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>1.</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 117, 562, 135]]<|/det|>

<mark>[3]

<mark>[Total: 11]

<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 430, 88]]<|/det|>
Fig. 6.1 shows a road next to the sea.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 98, 803, 338]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 355, 532, 373]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 418, 771, 437]]<|/det|>

<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 181, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
A cyclist travelling along the road notices that a cool breeze is blowing from the sea to the land.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 117, 920, 149]]<|/det|>
Explain how convection produces this breeze. You may include a diagram if it helps your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Fig. 7.1 is a full-scale diagram of a small nail N in front of a thin converging lens. The line L represents the lens.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[57, 114, 950, 393]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 406, 579, 425]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 438, 425, 456]]<|/det|>
The focal length of the lens is 3.0 cm.

<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 500, 707, 518]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 655, 920, 673]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 685, 144, 703]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<label>(i)</label>

By drawing on Fig. 7.1, find the position of the image I of N and add image I to the diagram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 763, 180, 781]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 763, 648, 781]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 826, 920, 843]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 856, 180, 874]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 856, 672, 874]]<|/det|>
State the name given to a lens when it is used in this way.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 887, 920, 906]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 918, 920, 935]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 860, 89]]<|/det|>
Fig. 8.1 shows two vertical, cylindrical tubes and a cylindrical magnet all held in a vacuum.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 97, 804, 301]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 313, 591, 331]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 8.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[395, 313, 591, 331]]<|/det|>
(not to scale)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 345, 918, 377]]<|/det|>
One tube is made of plastic and the other tube is made of copper. The two cylindrical tubes have identical dimensions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 390, 697, 408]]<|/det|>
The magnetic field of the small, cylindrical magnet is extremely strong.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 421, 593, 440]]<|/det|>
Initially, the magnet is at rest at the top of the plastic tube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 453, 918, 485]]<|/det|>
The magnet is released and it falls through the plastic tube without experiencing a resistive force. The magnet takes 0.67 s to fall to the lower end of the plastic tube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 500, 144, 518]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 500, 457, 518]]<|/det|>
The mass of the magnet is 0.012 kg.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 530, 912, 548]]<|/det|>
Calculate the kinetic energy of the magnet when it reaches the lower end of the plastic tube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 715, 920, 733]]<|/det|>
<form>kinetic energy = .......................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 746, 148, 765]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 746, 920, 780]]<|/det|>
The magnet is then held at the top of the copper tube and released. As it falls through the copper tube, an electric current is generated in the copper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 794, 181, 812]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 794, 559, 812]]<|/det|>
Explain why there is a current in the copper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 826, 918, 844]]<|/det|>
<form>........................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 858, 918, 875]]<|/det|>
<form>........................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 887, 920, 904]]<|/det|>
<form>........................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[875, 887, 920, 905]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 180, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 801, 88]]<|/det|>
The current in the copper produces a magnetic field of its own in the tube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 102, 836, 119]]<|/det|>
The magnet falls much more slowly in the copper tube than in the plastic tube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 133, 693, 150]]<|/det|>
Explain why the magnet falls more slowly in the copper tube.

<mark>[Total: 8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 106, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 72, 747, 91]]<|/det|>
Two of the isotopes of hydrogen are hydrogen-2 ( \(_1^2 \text{H}\) ) and hydrogen-3 ( \(_1^3 \text{H}\) ).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 144, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 103, 180, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 102, 631, 121]]<|/det|>
State one similarity in the composition of their nuclei.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 133, 920, 151]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 164, 180, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 163, 821, 183]]<|/det|>
Describe how a nucleus of hydrogen-3 differs from a nucleus of hydrogen-2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 227, 920, 245]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 257, 146, 275]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 257, 920, 306]]<|/det|>
In a nuclear fusion reactor, a nucleus of hydrogen-2 fuses with a nucleus of hydrogen-3 at an extremely high temperature. This fusion reaction produces an isotope of element X and releases a neutron.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 320, 181, 339]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 320, 920, 354]]<|/det|>
Explain why an extremely high temperature is needed when forcing these two nuclei together.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 457, 920, 475]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 488, 181, 507]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 488, 710, 507]]<|/det|>
Using nuclide notation, complete the equation for this reaction.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 532, 584, 555]]<|/det|>
\[^{2}_{1}\mathrm{H} + ^{3}_{1}\mathrm{H}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[893, 567, 920, 586]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]
